data.title: Test: Explorer Sorting settings
data.body:
Test for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5222, https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22529, https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29329, https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11823

Complexity: 2

- [x] Windows - **@michelkaporin**
- [x] macOS - **@sandy081**
- [x] Linux - **@isidorn**

A new setting `explorer.sortOrder` was added with many options to control the explorer sorting. Verify the sorting settings make sense to you and work properly:
* `filesFirst`: files are sorted before folders, sort order otherwise same as default
* `mixed`: files and folders are not sorted separately
* `modified`: files and folders are sorted separately by last modified and the sorting updates based on file change
* `type`: files and folders are sorted separately by file type

data.title: .config/Code/ dir gets large
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.0 (b8cd5b9556d8b70ea560d35b903422363f6c5c40, 2017-07-10T20:36:40.018Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 3.16.0-4-amd64
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
python|don|0.6.7
cpptools|ms-|0.12.0
---

Problem:
VSCode consumes 600 MB of my home dir. In .config/Code/ User/, CachedData/ and Cache/ use about 200 MB each. Our home dirs are on a network drive and are limited by a quota. I have no say about it's size.

Some suggestions to mitigate this:

- In Linux caches should be stored in ~/.cache/ which I can symlink to local storage.
- Setting to change location of addons or large storage.
- Perhaps advertise how much space addons require

data.title: Test: Improved --wait behaviour
data.body:
Test for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/18199 and https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/28661

Complexity: 3

- [x] Windows - **@egamma**
- [x] macOS - **@weinand**
- [x] Linux - **@joaomoreno**

VS Code can be started with the `--wait` argument from the command line and this will cause the terminal to wait until the VS Code instance is closed. A popular use case is to configure VS Code as git editor to edit git commit messages (see https://stackoverflow.com/questions/30024353/how-to-use-visual-studio-code-as-default-editor-for-git)

The implementation of this feature was rewritten to fix https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/18199. Verify using the CLI (e.g. `code --wait <path to some file>`):
* you get back to the prompt when starting an initial instance and closing that instance
* same when starting a second instance and closing that instance or all instances
* same when starting an initial instance, opening a second window and closing the first window

In addition, we will close the window when the last editor is closed of that instance (this is https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/28661). Verify:
* the window closes and you get back to the prompt when closing the last editor of the instance that was opened with `--wait`

Finally, verify that VS Code can still be used as git editor as outlined in https://stackoverflow.com/questions/30024353/how-to-use-visual-studio-code-as-default-editor-for-git

data.title: Missing Octicons usage documentation
data.body:
I discovered by chance that in many places VSC replaces a placeholder like this `$(icon-name)` with an icon, and that the supported icons can be seen [here](https://octicons.github.com/).

Other than a tiny reference [here](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensions/example-word-count#_customizing-the-status-bar) to this feature I believe it is completely undocumented, or at least I wasn't able to find anything on Google.

I believe such useful feature deserves proper documentation.

data.title: Default keyboard shortcuts for Accept Incoming / Current gone
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.0
- OS Version: Linux

After updating to 1.14 `merge-conflict.accept.current` and `merge-conflict.accept.incoming` no longer have their keyboard shortcut Alt+M, 1 / Alt+M, 2 assigned to them. I found them really handy and would like to keep my custom keybindings as short as possible (makes it easier when switching machines or sitting in front of another person's VS Code).

data.title: React.createElement intellisense
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:18:47.188Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscodeZoom|chr|0.0.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install `@types/react`
2. Create a ts file and paste:

```
import * as React from 'react'

interface Props { test: string }

class El extends React.Component<Props, any> { }

React.createElement(El, { test })
```

3. The intellisense of `test` in the last line is broken:
 a. When I start typing `test` the intellisense is NOT showing `test`
 b. When I finish typing `test` the intellisense suddenly finds and properly shows `test` (too late though)
 c. If I completely erase `test` from the last line, I get `Property 'test' is missing in type '{}'.` error as expected.

I guess the problem is that the intellisense for the second parameter of `createElement` is be based on the type of the first parameter. 

EDIT: It is not `React` specific. The same issue also appears when using `Mithril` and other libraries.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: createTerminal doesn't run js files on windows
data.body:
In my plugin, I'm running a js file in the terminal using createTerminal. This works fine in linux and osx, but on windows it doesn't. It opens the terminal with the right name but the contents stay black instead of printing the output from the js file. Clicking with the mouse inside the empty terminal results in the console opening and displaying the following two errors:

```
[uncaught exception]: TypeError: Cannot read property 'NaN' of undefined
onError @ index.js:5
```
```
index.js:5 TypeError: Cannot read property 'NaN' of undefined
    at SelectionManager._onSingleClick (C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\node_modules\xterm\lib\SelectionManager.js:228:71)
    at SelectionManager._onMouseDown (C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\node_modules\xterm\lib\SelectionManager.js:192:22)
    at HTMLDivElement.SelectionManager._initListeners._mouseDownListener (C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\node_modules\xterm\lib\SelectionManager.js:53:67)
onError @ index.js:5
```

Minimal code to reproduce is putting the following code in the activate function of my plugin:

_main.js_
```
var term = vscode.window.createTerminal({name: "Terminal Test", shellPath: "c:/users/me/test.js"} )
term.show()
```
(I've tried multiple ways to write this createTerminal line; relative and absolute path, using "node" as the shellPath and passing the js file in the shellArgs, but all end up with the same result)

_test.js_
```
#!/usr/bin/env node

console.log('Test')
```

- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: windows 10 (tested on 64bit machine and 32bit vm)

My vscode installation is fresh and unused, so not a single other plugin installed

I hope this is not me doing something stupid, in which case I apologise for posting here instead of stackoverflow. Looking at the stacktrace it does seem to be an internal issue with xterm, although the click error might be unrelated to the fact that is just doesn't start the js file. 

I hope someone can give me a hand with this, or check if it's indeed an issue with vsc itself.

data.title: Perl: Incorrect Syntax Highlighting
EH debugging: identify debug window through session ID
data.body:
This issue is about enabling a multi-root workspace to launch and debug extensions via extension host debugging.

We have code in the extension host to broadcast messages to that window which launched the extension host. We use the simple extension development path as a way to find the target window. This cannot work anymore once you are in a multi-root workspace where you can have multiple paths (and you can have multiple windows with the same path).

After talking to @weinand we think that the best approach would be that the broadcast message is send to simply all windows and that it includes the debug session ID. With that information we can do the correct thing where we receive the message (in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/electron-browser/debugService.ts#L162). 

I have pushed the change to broadcast to all windows and I added some workaround for now to enable EH debugging by simply checking if a EH session is active. This unblocks us for now. Once we have the debug session ID, we can do the real fix.

data.title: VS Code Connection to TFVC very slow
data.body:
Hello,

I connected VSCode folder to TFVC Source Control. I am able to  checkout files and then modify them and then check them in. However, after modifying code in VSCode it take a while for them to be checked out under Included changes section. Why is it taking so long for the files to appear under Included Changes in VSCode once the change is made? 

I'm evaluating VSCode integration with TFVC instead of Git. But it seems like integration with TFVC is very slow and may just avoid using VSCode altogether if our company just sticks with TFS instead of Git.

Will this improve? 

FYI-  TFS is locally installed on the same computer.

Dan

data.title: Support external diff algorithms in internal diff editor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
While #15661 asks for the ability to launch external diff programs in _their own user interface_ I'd rather like VSCode to parse the patch formatted output of another (probably mainly cli?) diff tool and **show the results  in the regular built-in diff editor**

In #15661 @joaomoreno suggested writing an **extension** but I suppose this here would not be possible with an extension, right?

Just like in #15661 one of the use cases I have in mind is using **[git's built in diff algorithms](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-diff#git-diff---diff-algorithmpatienceminimalhistogrammyers)**. For that use case I'd also love to see an option that respects what is being set in **git's settings** (although I guess _this_ should be possible to be managed in an **extension** when the base functionality of using external diff algorithms in the internal diff editor is implemented, right?)

data.title: Default to use font with programming ligatures if they are installed
data.body: Just a suggestion, VSCode should set `editor.fontLigatures` to `true` if it finds programming ligature fonts in the user's system

data.title: [TAB] not inserting tab character when using "Indent using Spaces"
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open new file (plain text), type `hello`<kbd>TAB</kbd>`world`

Expected: Tab is inserted, text is 

```
hello	world
```
Actual:  Spaces (4) are inserted, not tabs, text is 

```
hello   world
```

* Changing indentation from space to tabs yields expected behavior. 


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

_Edit: Markdown_
